Award.AwardTitle: AutoMentor: Virtual Mentoring and Assessment in Computer Games for STEM Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project builds on existing research and extends it to include a computational model of participation in a community of practice. The products include an automated mentoring system that uses natural language conversations to help students learn about science and technology and an assessment/analysis protocol to quantify students' STEM behavior. It extends automated tutoring with an automated mentoring technology, AutoMentor, and combines it with Epistemic Network Analysis. AutoMentor is implemented in Land Science, a multi-player urban planning game, and tested by the Massachusetts Audubon Society with approximately 700 middle school aged students either in after-school or in-school programs.

Pioneering work drawn from three partner institutions inform the design of the system. These include intelligent tutoring (Graesser, University of Memphis), assessment (Mislevy, University of Maryland), and game-based learning (Shaffer, University of Wisconsin-Madison). The core technologies are supported by expertise in computer science, science content, measurement, and STEM educational programming. The project has the potential to transform all three core areas by providing a fully implementable system that supports student learning substantive content through immersion in a STEM processes. The PIs anticipate that this will be integral to learning systems of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STEM Virtual Internships with Automated Professional Mentoring

A key educational goal in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is to help students learn to think like STEM professionals in the real world do. Real-world educational experiences, such as internships and cooperative research, help students learn both the content and the practices of a particular field, but few K-12 students can access such experiences. 

To address these problems, the Epistemic Games Group at the University of Wisconsin has developed a number of virtual internships, web-based simulations of real-world work in STEM fields such as engineering and environmental science. In a virtual internship, students play the role of interns at a fictitious company. The company gives them a challenging STEM problem, such as designing a robotic exoskeleton for rescue workers or preparing a redevelopment plan that addresses social and environmental issues in a city. Students then work individually and in small project teams to solve the problem: they read research reports, learn about stakeholders, perform virtual experiments, and use simulated professional tools to collect and analyze data. At the end of the virtual internship, they write a final proposal in which they describe and justify their solutions. 

Teachers who have used virtual internships with their students appreciate the opportunities provided. “The kids take away a sense of accomplishment,” one teacher said. “That they’ve taken this entire product from a design all the way through to a presentation. ... And even though it was high pressure and very fast paced, they get so much out of it and that is truly a work experience. And the fact that they’re getting a chance to have an internship is so important because we don't have enough internships to go around.” 

Virtual internships provide a realistic experience in part because student learning is guided by an interactive STEM mentor. Mentors provide advice and encouragement, answer questions, give students feedback on their work, and generally help students get the most from their virtual internship experience. Providing good mentoring, however, is a challenging task, and one mentor can only interact with a small number of students at a time. To expand access to virtual internships and ensure high-quality professional mentoring, this project, a collaborative effort led by the University of Wisconsin in partnership with the University of Memphis, the University of Georgia, the University of Maryland, and the Massachusetts Audubon Society, developed tools to automate several aspects of the mentoring that students receive.

By implementing automated mentoring features in virtual internships, human mentors can focus on the tasks that artificial intelligence cannot yet accomplish. In addition, mentors need less training, and they can work with more students at once. “It was easy to be trained and then effectively implement in the classroom, which does not always happen,” noted one teacher who used a virtual internship with automated professional mentoring. “And that makes it easy for a teacher.”

These features, known collectively as the Automentor, perform a number of tasks in virtual internships. The Automentor can assess student work, such as research notebook entries; identify student questions and suggest appropriate responses; help students with time management and deadlines; identify when students have correctly answered a question; and generally help mentors consistently provide effective and efficient professional mentoring.
